title-group.article-title: Self, Memory, and the Self-Reference Effect
title-group.subtitle: An Examination of Conceptual and Methodological Issues

author-notes.corresp: Stanley B. Klein, University of California, 551 Ucen Road, Santa Barbara, CA 93106-9660, USA Email: klein@psych.ucsb.edu

abstract.p: The author argues that the self is a multifaceted entity that does not easily submit to clear and precise description. The aspect of self studied by most investigators is actually a subset of the cognitive and neural underpinnings of “self” and not the “self” of first-person subjectivity. The author then looks at the dominant theoretical treatment of human long-term memory—the systems approach—and examines how the construct of “self” is situated in this framework. Finally, he reviews the best-known paradigm for exploring the role of self in memory—the self-reference effect (SRE) manipulation. He argues that there is not one SRE but rather a family of related SREs that are influenced by a variety of variables and contexts. Accordingly, researchers must exercise caution when attempting to draw conclusions about the self from the results of SRE memory performance.

body.p: I have three goals in this article. First, I argue that the main construct under discussion—the self—is a multifaceted entity that does not easily submit to clear and precise description. As I hope to make clear, the aspect of self studied by most investigators is actually a subset of the cognitive and neural underpinnings of “self” and not the self of first-person subjectivity. Second, I take a look at what currently is the dominant theoretical treatment of human long-term memory—the systems approach (e.g., Foster & Jelicic, 1999)—and examine how the construct of “self” is situated in this theoretical framework. Finally, I review the best-known paradigm for exploring the role of self in memory—the self-reference effect (SRE) manipulation. I argue that, similar to the other constructs at play (i.e., self and memory), there is not one SRE but rather a family of related SREs that are influenced by a variety of variables and contexts.

I conclude that great care is required when investigators attempt to draw inferences about the self from tests using the SRE because (a) while the SRE provides insight into memory-based self-knowledge, it does not warrant any conclusions about the self of conscious awareness, and (b) when using the self-reference paradigm to test the relation between self and memory, conclusions must rest heavily on a variety of factors including the memory system(s) being used by the task, the type of stimulus items used, the degree of familiarity with task referents, and the conditions adopted as controls, among others.

sec.title: The Self and Its Relation to Memory
sec.p: The self and memory share a complicated relation. The act of experiencing a personal memory presupposes a sense that the memory is not just any memory, but my memory. At the same time, knowledge of self, by most accounts, is based on the content of memory. The apparent circularity of this relation, and the ensuing infinite regress it portends, has long been recognized by philosophers (e.g., Locke, 1690/1731; Schechtman, 1996; see Bernecker, 2010, for review) and psychologists (e.g., James, 1890; Warnock, 1987; see Klein, 2001, 2010, for review).

sec.title: Different ways of knowing the self
sec.p: Fortunately, the resolution of a number of conceptual and definitional problems with the concepts of self and memory may help break the apparent circularity. I start with the self.

Psychologists studying the self often do not differentiate between aspects of and the ways in which they use the word self. Along these lines, Klein and Gangi (2010) suggested that Bertrand Russell’s (1912/1999; 1913/1992; see also James, 1909/1996) distinction between knowledge by acquaintance and knowledge by description provides a way to break the conceptual impasse posed by the definitional entanglement between self and memory. Russell proposed that we have knowledge by acquaintance when we know something via direct personal contact (sensory or introspective) and exhibit that knowledge by using appropriately referential terms when we communicate with others. With respect to the self, this is seen in the ease with which I talk about the self as well as understand talk about self by others.

However, when we attempt to make explicit the precise referent of the word “self”—when asked to describe what the word “self” means—problems quickly arise (similar concerns have been voiced by philosophers of varied theoretical commitments; for example, Lund, James, Kant, Sartre, Hume, and Husserl, Stawson, Zahavi). Despite centuries devoted to the task, it has proven notoriously difficult to provide a set of propositions capable of transforming our acquired knowledge of self into a satisfying description of what a self is.

How, for example, can one explain experienced identity of the self over time—that is, the diachronic self? Locke (1690/1731) argued that a continuity of consciousness (what we now would call episodic long-term memory) might do the trick, but issues soon raised by Thomas Reid and other philosophers called attention to serious problems with Locke’s criterion (for review and discussion, see Dainton, 2008; Klein & Nichols, in press; Noonan, 1989; Parfit, 1984; Shoemaker & Swinburne, 1984; Slors, 2001).

Equally vexing problems arise when we attempt to explain the perceived phenomenological unity of the self at a single moment in time—the synchronic self. Specifically, how do we account for the ways in which a diversity of images (visual, acoustic, tactile, etc.), sensations, and thoughts appear to merge into a single, unified experience of self-awareness (the so-called “binding” problem of conscious awareness; e.g., Dainton, 2008; Damasio, 1999; Lowe, 1996; Lund, 2005)?

These and a host of other contentious ontological issues involving the word “self” (e.g., consciousness, subjectivity, self-awareness, free will, explanatory gap, mind/body, subject/object, personal continuity, etc.) make clear that insufficient progress has been made on the task of describing what we are talking about when we use the word “self” (for reviews, see Baillie, 1993; Dainton, 2008; Eccles, 1994; Johnstone, 1970; Lund, 2005; Madell, 1984; Schechtman, 1996; Shoemaker & Swinburne, 1984; Strawson, 2009; Vierkant, 2003; for an historical review of problems arising in the use of the term “self”; see Sorabji, 2006).

Although this might seem a cause for great concern among psychologists—after all, William James (1890) argued that the self is the fundamental unit of analysis for a science of mental life, the problem about which everything else revolves (e.g., James, 1890, p. 221)—such concern is not always apparent from perusal of articles in contemporary (nonanalytic) psychological literatures (e.g., social, cognitive, developmental, neuropsychological, brain imaging; see Klein, 2010). Compounding this lack of attention to the conceptual problems, the number of research papers exploring self-related processes in psychology and neuroscience has been proliferating at a staggering pace. Commenting in 1971 on the explosion of empirical articles on the self appearing in the 20 years since the behaviorist movement in America had given way to appreciation of the importance of inferring mental structures from the behavior of persons (e.g., Gardner, 1985; Klein & Kihlstrom, 1998; Neisser, 1967), Gergen (1971) recorded an astonishing 2,000 studies published on the self during the previous two decades. Approximately 25 years later, John Kihlstrom et al. (1988) identified dozens of “hot” research areas in which the word self served as prefix (thus occupying the central position with regard to the topics addressed), such as self-awareness, self-concept, self-control, self-verification, self-perception, self-handicapping, self-reference, self-regulation, self-schema, self-image, and self-stereotypes. More recently, Klein and Gangi (2010) surveyed the table of contents of what, at the time, was the most recent issue of the journal Self and Identity. They identified an equally rich collection of self-hyphenated research areas, a large number of which were carryovers from those identified 22 years earlier by Kihlstrom and colleagues.

But what exactly is the “self” that serves as the object of this diverse set of predicates: What is it that is being verified, conceptualized, controlled, esteemed, deceived, referenced, regulated, depleted, and handicapped? Although this question has led to psychological models of self, dating back more than 100 years (e.g., Calkins, 1915; Conway, 2005; Gallagher & Shear, 1999; Greenwald, 1981; James, 1890; Kihlstrom et al., 1988; Kihlstrom & Klein, 1994; Mischel, 1977; Neisser, 1988; Samsonovich & Nadel, 2005; Stern, 1985), it is extremely difficult to find a coherent and convincing descriptive account of the self, per se. Rather, these articles typically describe the neurological and cognitive mechanisms that appear causally responsible for the knowledge available to the self of subjective experience.

sec.title: The neural self of science and the subjective self of first-person phenomenology
sec.p: In this section, I turn attention to what can be asserted with reasonable empirically warranted confidence about the self. Specifically, I discuss what Klein (in press-b) calls the epistemological self—the behavioral, affective, cognitive, and neural systems assumed to be causally responsible (at least in part) for providing the subjective self with knowledge of whom and what it is (for reviews, see Klein, 2004, 2010; Strawson, 2009). I then point to an apparent incompatibility between treating the self as both the subject of experience (i.e., an object) and the agent of experience (i.e., a subject; for more detailed treatment, see Earle, 1972; Klein, in press-a; Strawson, 2009; Zahavi, 2005). This latter aspect of self I call the ontological self (e.g., Klein, 2004, in press-b).

It is a fact of scientific inquiry and personal experience that the “self” of an individual is able to learn about the individual in which it is situated and even experience itself as a knower (the validity of this statement hinges critically on whether one is referring to the epistemological or ontological self—see below for discussion. For a classic treatment, see, James, 1890; more modern accounts can be found in Crispin, Smith, & Macdonald, 1998; Earle, 1955; Gennaro, 1996; Klein, 2004; Rosenthal, 1986). Scientific accounts of the mechanisms that allow information about the self to be acquired, stored, and retrieved are flourishing in academic psychology, even if troubling ontological issues remain mostly unaddressed (e.g., Klein, in press-a; Klein & Gangi, 2010).

In particular, considerable progress has been made describing the cognitive and neurological bases of the epistemological self (e.g., Conway, 2005; Klein, 2010; Klein, Cosmides, Tooby, & Chance, 2002; Neisser, 1988; Samsonovich & Nadel, 2005). This is because, unlike ontological questions, the epistemological self—that is, neurological bases of self-knowledge—are empirically testable, and thus amenable to scientific analysis. By contrast, the ontological self, the self of personal experience, is too poorly understood to bear the definitional adequacy required of the terms of a causal relation between self and memory (e.g., Earle, 1955; Hasker, 1999; Klein, in press-a, in press-b; Metzinger, 2009; Strawson, 2009). Not surprisingly, many researchers (intentionally or otherwise) sidestep this difficulty, relying on their readers’ familiarity with the term “self” (i.e., the self of subjective experience), derived from years of knowledge by acquaintance, to confer a sense of confidence that he or she knows to what it is the author refers. But the basic problem remains—We are unclear what it is we are referring to when we apply the label “self.” This is a serious problem.1

Compounding the difficulty surrounding the study of the self, researchers may fail to appreciate fully that the self as subjectivity—what I am calling the ontological self—is not the object of their experimental studies. Indeed, it cannot be the object of their studies. Objectivity is based on the assumption that an act or object exists independent of any individual’s awareness of it (e.g., Earle, 1955; Foster, 1991; Nagel, 1974); it is something “other” than the self. When objectivity is the stance adopted by the self to study itself, the self must, of necessity, be directed toward what is not the self but rather to some “other” that serves as the self’s object (e.g., Earle, 1972; Husserl, 1964; Klein, in press-a; Lund, 2005; Nagel, 1974; Zahavi, 2005). To study myself as an object, I must transform myself into an “other,” into a “not-self.”

Thus, the ontological or subjective self is not, and cannot, be an object for itself and still maintain its subjectivity. Paradoxically, we can achieve objectivity of the ontological self only at the cost of losing awareness of our self as a subjective center.

We can (as some have) adopt what have been called self-reflexive, meta, or higher-order-thoughts (e.g., Gennaro, 1996; Rosenthal, 1986; Terrace & Metcalfe, 2005), in which a previous experience or thought subsequently is taken as the object of the intentionality of consciousness (what I am calling the ontological or subjective self). Indeed, in our personal life, we commonly do so (e.g., Dennett, 1996). But in this case, the original subjectivity has relinquished its status as subject to become an object or “other” for the self to consider (Klein, in press-a). Accordingly, a vicious regress of higher-order-thoughts is likely to ensue (e.g., I think about the pain I felt; I think about the thought of the pain I felt; I think about the thought of the thought of the pain I felt . . . ad infinitum).

Clearly then, a thought may become an object and be apprehended by the subjective self. As an object, it is dependent on physiological or neural or other conditions. But the ontological self does not supply those conditions (e.g., Earle, 1972; Husserl, 1964; Klein, in press-a). The thought does not depend on its apprehension (i.e., the thought is not numerically identical or reducible to awareness: It enjoys an independent existence as a property of the mind). Once apprehended by the ontological self, the thought becomes an “other” (i.e., an object of the self’s subjectivity) in the manner all objects (both external and internal) must, of necessity, become when apprehended.

Accordingly, we never observe the ontological self directly. Rather, what we encounter in self-awareness is the object of that awareness or apprehension. The awareness itself remains hidden in the background, an unseen and unseeable subjectivity that provides the conscious self with awareness of its acts, perceptions, and thoughts.

These ideas are not new. For example, they have considerable overlap with the view (often attributed to 19th century philosopher Franz Brentano) that self-conscious awareness of necessity must be intentional. This means that the ontological (i.e., conscious) self must be about some object or idea other than itself; it must have an object (whether physical or mental); pure consciousness, absent its object, cannot be known (see also James, 1890; Lund, 2005; Zahavi, 2005). In short, consciousness devoid of an intentional object is not possible, although various forms of Eastern wisdom traditions take issue with this idea, positing the possibility of attaining and experiencing pure consciousness (i.e., consciousness absent an object; see Forman, 1990; Siderits, 2003; Siderits, Thompson, & Zahavi, 2011).

Given these considerations, the ontological self would seem a particularly poor candidate for scientific exploration—an enterprise predicated on understanding objects and their relations. Science is the world of publically observable and physically measurable objects and events. Because nothing can be an object for the self unless it is “other” to the self, it follows that the self cannot objectively apprehend itself as itself (Earle, 1972; Foster, 1991; Loizou, 2000; Lund, 2005; Nagel, 1974; Zahavi, 2005). For the subjective self to become part of the scientific world, it would have to forfeit its subjectivity. Scientific analysis therefore has the unintended consequence of eliminating the object under discussion—the ontological self—from the discussion.

Nor is the ontological self something one can locate via inference. I do not have to guess that I exist. I am immediately aware of my self as myself, as a unique subjectivity (e.g., Earle, 1972; Husserl, 1964; Krueger, 2011; Lund, 2005). And I am immediately aware of my feelings, beliefs, memories, knowledge, decisions, judgments, and acts (i.e., the domain of psychological processes that constitute the epistemological self) as mine. These things cannot cause themselves, via some scientifically accepted mechanism of physical forces, to be known (Earle, 1955). How, for example, could the future, which influences subjectivity in the form of thought and planning (e.g., Klein, Robertson, & Delton, 2010, 2011), be physically causal when it does not even exist? Rather, mentation (about the future, for example) can be treated as an object of awareness and thus can be grasped or apprehended by the ontological self. But, lacking an objective existence, the future is obviously not amenable to empirical analysis.

Given these issues, some writers (e.g., epiphenomenalists, eliminative materialists, physicalists) have tried to banish the ontological self from investigation, to argue that it is an illusion, the anachronistic myth of a folk-psychology that is being replaced by advances in the neurosciences (most of these arguments appeal to anticipated, but not yet realized, innovations in the neurosciences—hence the “promissory note” aspect of the eliminativist program; e.g., Churchland, 1986; for a critique, see Hasker, 1999).

Exemplifying such thinking, Metzinger (2009) recently pronounced the self to be nothing more than an illusion posited to explain acts and thoughts that ultimately will be reducible to the actions of neurons and their interconnections. But after the dust of promised reductive analyses clears, a simple question remains—To or for whom is the self an illusion? There is a mystery here that will not go away by sweeping it under a metaphysical rug.

In sum, when psychologists focus on the self, more often than not, they are actually investigating the multiplicity of neural systems assumed to provide the ontological self with knowledge. A tacit assumption is that there is a substantive, objective self, which, like any object (provided proper tools are available), can be treated as “other” and thus studied scientifically (e.g., James, 1909/1996; LeShan & Margenau, 1982). Although this assumption has merit for the study of epistemological sources of self-knowledge, we often fail to appreciate that (a) the subjective self is not an object, but rather an awareness, a consciousness, and as such is not privy to anyone but itself, and (b) profoundly important differences exist between self as a subjective entity (the ontological self) and the self as types of knowledge available to that subjectivity (i.e., the epistemological bases of self-knowledge; for discussion, see Earle, 1972; Foster, 1991; Giles, 1997; Hasker, 1999; Krueger, 2011; Lewis, 1986; Lowe, 1996; Lund, 2005). These two forms or aspects of “self” are contingently related but are not conceptually reducible. By conflating them, we often assume that we are casting empirical light on one (the ontological self) while experimentally exploring the other (neurally based sources of knowledge about the person we are—that is, the epistemological self).

sec.title: Summing up so far
sec.p: To summarize, I draw a sharp distinction between two aspects of self, aspects whose different properties play a central role in how behavioral scientists should conduct research and theorize about the self. Those aspects are the following:

list-item.p: The Ontological Self—the self experienced as single, subjective, and phenomenologically given (e.g., Klein, in press-a, in press-b; Strawson, 2009). As self-experience, it entails subjectivity, which, in turn, implies that does it not allow for treatment as an object of analysis (see above; also see Earle, 1972; Klein, in press-b; Strawson, 2009; Zahavi, 2005). That is, the ontological self is not clearly or easily reducible to neural function.2 That being said, it also likely is the case that the ontological self, being the subject, or experiencer, is informed (in some manner) by experiences both external and internal to the organism. It also is possible that it contributes causally to the organism’s thoughts, decisions, and actions (although this latter claim introduces a host of contentious issues about epiphenomenalism, causal closure under physicalism, etc., discussion of which would take us far beyond the scope of this article; for discussion, see Hasker, 1999; Klein, in press-a). This is the self of acquaintance.

Epistemological Self—the assumed neurological bases of self experiences.3 The epistemological self is propertied by features and processes of the various systems of our material bodies. These systems (presumed to be neural in nature) in some way or ways provide the raw, as well as processed, data of self-experience—that is, they provide content for the ontological self. From a materialist (or emergent materialist; e.g., Bunge, 2010) stance, such aspects of self are amenable to study and constitute the major body of findings that psychologists present when discussing and researching what they term “the” self. This is the self of description.

sec.p: My stance is this: We will ultimately not make sufficient progress coming to terms with our object of inquiry—the self—until we acknowledge (in Jamesian fashion) that the self is a multiplicity, both as pertains to (a) two intimately related, yet metaphysically separable aspects of the term “self” (i.e., ontological vs. epistemological), as well as (b) within each of these two self aspects there exist the possibility (and, in the case of the epistemological self, the reality) of functionally dissociable elements (e.g., the semantic and episodic sources of self-knowledge). Until we not only recognize but also fully embrace the different “types” of selves we conjoin in both our thought and research (for reviews, see Klein, in press-a, in press-b; Strawson, 2009), progress on what Chalmers (1996) described as the “hard question” likely will remain elusive.

sec.title: Types of epistemological self-knowledge: A partial taxonomy
sec.p: As noted in the previous section, there is a diversity of self-predicated terms that have received empirical attention in psychology. And, herein resides an apparent paradox—the self as a subjective, singular point of view (i.e., the ontological self) is informed by, and perhaps constituted from, a multiplicity of neural sources (i.e., the epistemological self), yet we experience the self as a phenomenological unity (e.g., Damasio, 1999; Earle, 1972; Lund, 2005; White, 1991).

For example, neuropsychological studies of self suggest that the singular self of everyday experience actually is informed by a number of functionally isolable neurocognitive systems (e.g., Katzko, 2003; Klein, 2004, 2010; Neisser, 1988; Stern, 1985). These include, but are not limited to, the following:

list-item.p: Episodic memories of one’s life events.
Semantic summary representations of one’s personality traits.
Semantic knowledge of facts about one’s life.

An experience of continuity through time: The “I” experienced now is connected to the “I” experienced at previous points (as well as later points) in one’s life. Episodic memory is known to contribute heavily to this ability.
A sense of personal agency and ownership: The belief—or experience—that “I” (agency) am the cause of “my own” (ownership) thoughts and actions.
The ability to self-reflect: To form meta-representations where the agent is the self, and make inferences on the basis of those representations.
The physical self: The ability to represent and recognize one’s body (e.g., in mirrors, photographs).

sec.p: Although these sources each contribute to the experience of self as a subjective singularity, taken individually, they are functionally independent (for a theoretical review and empirical documentation of the bases for this partial taxonomy of neural sources of the epistemological self, see Klein, 2010; Klein & Gangi, 2010; Klein, German, Cosmides, & Gabriel, 2004; Klein & Nichols, in press). That is, while in normal individuals, sources of self-knowledge work together to create our sense of self as a subjective unity (e.g., Damasio, 1999; White, 1991), taken separately none of these systems are either logically or empirically necessary to maintain the experience of the self as a singular, subjective point of view.

sec.title: Memory
sec.p: This section of the article is focused on epistemological self-knowledge derived from memory (i.e., Points 1, 2, and 3 above). Accordingly, understanding the relation between types of self-knowledge and memory needs to be made explicit. In what follows, I provide an account of my position.

Specifically, how does a person know that he or she possesses some characteristics but not others? How is this knowledge represented in and retrieved from memory? I have chosen to address these questions within the context of the position that long-term memory consists of multiple systems (for reviews of the memory systems debate, see Foster & Jelicic, 1999; Schacter & Tulving, 1994).

Psychologists generally agree that memory stores two basic types of information, procedural and declarative (e.g., Cohen, 1984; Klein, 2004; Parkin, 1993; Schacter & Tulving, 1994; Squire, 1987; Tulving, 1983, 1995). Procedural memory makes possible the acquisition and retention of motor, perceptual, and cognitive skills (e.g., knowing how to ride a bike); it consists of the nonconscious expression of acquired behavioral skills and cognitive procedures (e.g., Parkin, 1993; Tulving, 1985; Tulving & Schacter, 1990). Declarative memory consists in facts and beliefs about the world (e.g., knowing that canaries are yellow, knowing that Eli pitched a shutout yesterday). Conceptually, the difference between procedural and declarative memory largely coincides with Ryle’s (1949) classic distinction between knowing how (operating on the environment in ways difficult to verbalize) and knowing that (stating knowledge in the form of propositions).

Tulving (1983, 1985, 1993) distinguished two types or systems within declarative memory—episodic and semantic (see also Cermak, 1984; Furlong, 1951; Moscovitch, Yaschyshyn, Ziegler, & Nadel, 2000; Parkin, 1993). Semantic memory contains relatively generic, context-free knowledge about the world, such as Grapes are edible, 2 + 2 = 4 and Sacramento is the capital of California. Semantic memory usually lacks a source tag; that is, it is experienced as knowledge without regard to where and when that knowledge was obtained (e.g., Gennaro, 1996; Perner & Ruffman, 1994; Tulving, 1983, 1993, 1995; Wheeler et al., 1997). Semantic memory makes typically no reference to the self; it can, however, contain propositions expressing facts about the self (e.g., Stan Klein was born in New York), just as it can about other things in the world. But this information is known in the same way that one knows that 2 +2 = 4; it is not recollected or reexperienced vis-à-vis the context in which it originally was learned.

In contrast to semantic memory, the episodic memory system records events as having been experienced by the self in one’s personal past. When retrieved, these events are reexperienced in a quasi-perceptual way, with conscious awareness that “this happened to me” (e.g., Suddendorf & Corballis, 1997; Tulving, 1983, 1993; Wheeler et al., 1997). Every episodic memory, by definition, entails a mental representation of the self as the agent or recipient of some action, or as the stimulus or experiencer of some state. Examples of episodic memory are I remember eating chicken for supper yesterday evening; I recall having met with Judith last Monday.

Not surprisingly, the episodic component of declarative memory historically has been the focus of interest for psychologists studying the relation between self and memory. This is because retrieval from episodic memory is assumed to have a self-referential quality thought to be largely absent from other types of memorial experience (i.e., semantic and procedural; see Kihlstrom, Beer, & Klein, 2003; Klein, 2001; Klein, Cosmides, et al., 2002). By contrast, semantic memory traditionally was not assumed to be accompanied by awareness of reexperiencing one’s personal past (e.g., Klein, 2001; Perner & Ruffman, 1994; Tulving, 1993, 1995; Wheeler et al., 1997). I may know where I was born, but I do not know this by virtue of having recalled or reexperienced my birth. That is why this bit of personal history would be considered semantic knowledge, despite being about oneself.

However, semantic memory also contains a variety of self-referential information (see Klein, 2001; Klein & Loftus, 1993; 2004, 2010; Klein, Robertson, Gangi, & Loftus, 2008), thus rendering the assumption that episodic memory and the self share a unique relation tenuous at best. The failure to consider the possibility of self-referential information in both episodic and semantic long-term memory has had important, unintended consequences for many years on how researchers have interpreted findings from the most influential paradigm for exploring the memorial effects of self-reference: The SRE.

sec.title: A Resolution to the Apparent Circularity Between the Concepts of Self and Memory
sec.p: As noted at the start of this article, the apparent circularity of the relationship between self and memory has been a persistent thorn in the side of theorists interested in these two hypothesized mental entities. How can one examine the relation between the self and memory if the concepts by which they are known and described are inextricably entangled?

The goal of this section is to spell out the nature of the assumed tautology and to offer a possible solution. My proposed resolution is that the assumed circularity is more apparent than real, and that it can be successfully addressed once one recognizes that the self is not a unitary construct (nor, as we have seen, is memory). Rather, it admits to a multiplicity of related neural processes, systems, and types/levels of experience (e.g., Klein, in press-a; Klein & Gangi, 2010; Klein & Lax, 2010; Klein & Nichols, in press).

The prototypical example of the circular nature of the relation between self and memory is found in John Locke’s theory of self and memory (1690/1731). For Locke, what makes a person the same across time (i.e., diachronic personal identity) is relations of memory: It is by memory of a past action that I am identical with a past person. (Locke actually used the word “consciousness,” but his intended meaning is what we now call episodic memory; e.g., Klein & Nichols, in press; Shoemaker & Swinburne, 1984.)

As noted, Locke’s critics were quick to point out that for a mental state to count as my memory of a past action, it has to be the case that I was the one who performed the past action (e.g., Butler, 1736/1819; Reid, 1785). If it wasn’t me who performed the action, then my apparent recollection is simply a mistake, not a memory. As Butler (1736/1819) put it, “one should really think it self-evident, consciousness of personal identity presupposes, and therefore cannot constitute, personal identity” (p. 290). If memory presupposes self, then trying to give an account of self in terms of memory (and vice versa) seems hopeless.

However, the multiple natures of the concepts of self and of memory suggest that the general issue of self/memory circularity may be avoided. First, as previous discussion has made clear, the self as an ontological entity is not directly involved in memory per se. Rather, memory, with its epistemological contributions (including self-reference) is simply one source of the content that makes up our phenomenological experience of the self as subjectivity. For example, Lockean circularity refers to the role of episodic recollection in knowledge of self (i.e., the epistemological self). Yet, as we have seen, semantic memory also admits to various forms of self-knowledge. Although some have suggested that such knowledge can be used to temporally ground the self (e.g., Haslam, Jetten, Haslam, Pugliese, & Tonks, 2011; Rathbone, Moulin, & Conway, 2009), others have presented evidence that semantic self-knowledge may be necessary, but not sufficient for this purpose (e.g., Klein, Loftus, & Kihlstrom, 2002; Klein & Nichols, in press). Regardless how the debate turns out, it is clear that a variety of nonmemory factors play a role in contributing to self-diachronicity (e.g., physical features, ownership, agency, image), none of which can easily be seen as entailing the definitional circularity so often identified when diachronicity is assumed to be based on episodic memory. Accordingly, once the multifaceted nature of the epistemological self (and memory) is taken into account, the vicious regress can, at least in principle, be broken.

sec.title: Testing the Relation Between Memory and the Self: The SRE
sec.p: In one of the first demonstrations that information is remembered better when it is considered in relation to the self, Rogers, Kuiper, and Kirker (1977) used Craik and Tulving’s (1975) depth of processing methodology to examine the effects of various encoding strategies on incidental recall. Rogers et al. found that judging trait adjectives for self-descriptiveness (“Describes you?”) led to better recall than did structural (e.g., “Printed in capital letters?”), phonemic (e.g., “Rhymes with XXX?”), or semantic (e.g., “Means the same as XXX?”) encoding of the same material.

The superior recall for words encoded with respect to oneself (the SRE) generated much interest because it contradicted the prevailing belief among many psychologists that semantic encoding produces optimal retention within the depth of the processing framework (e.g., Craik & Tulving, 1975; Hyde & Jenkins, 1973). In addition, because the recall of self-referentially encoded material was assumed to be informative about the memorial properties of the self, the Rogers et al. (1977) paradigm seemed to offer a method for exploring the role of the self in memory.

sec.title: The Mechanisms Mediating the Effects of Self-Reference on Memory
sec.p: So, what causes the SRE? A large number of processes have been suggested. For example, the SRE has been proposed to reflect the operation of a variety of cognitive processes, including elaboration (e.g., Keenan & Baillet, 1980; Klein & Loftus, 1988; Rogers et al., 1977), organization (Klein & Kihlstrom, 1986; Klein & Loftus, 1988), evaluation (Ferguson, Rule, & Carlson, 1983; Zajonc, 1980), cognitive cueing (Bellezza, 1984), and distinctiveness (Bruss, 1986; Friedman & Pullyblank, 1982). Initially, none of these proposals emerged as definitive, partly because of the lack of a consistent pattern of results against which to evaluate them. In the absence of a clear understanding of the SRE, results obtained with the self-reference paradigm have been less useful in explicating the role of the self in memory than was originally expected. However, as subsequent experimental procedures (Klein & Loftus, 1988) and meta-analytic review (Symons & Johnson, 1997) have shown, two processes emerged as the most likely contenders—the elaborative processing hypothesis and the organizational processing hypothesis.

sec.title: The elaborative processing hypothesis
sec.p: Perhaps because the SRE initially was demonstrated using the depth-of-processing methodology, most investigators explained the effect in terms of Craik and Tulving’s (1975) elaborative processing model of memory facilitation (Brown, Keenan, & Potts, 1986; Ganellen & Carver, 1985; Katz, 1987; Keenan & Baillet, 1980; Kendzierski, 1980; Kuiper & Rogers, 1979; Rogers et al., 1977). Elaborative processing refers to operations that result in the encoding of information specific to an individual item (Craik, 1979; Einstein & Hunt, 1980; Klein & Kihlstrom, 1986). That is, elaborating a word entails the formation of multiple associations between it and extralist (e.g., items not presented as part of a list of to-be-remembered stimuli) material in memory (e.g., Bellezza, Cheesman, & Reddy, 1977).

Elaborating the word dance, for example, may involve encoding it along with information such as “taking ballet lessons” and “going to the senior prom,” whereas the word music may prompt the encoding of information such as “buying a record album” and “playing the piano.” The process of drawing on item-specific information in memory to embellish the encoded representation of a word benefits recall by creating multiple routes for retrieval; in addition, item-specific information supports inference-based reconstruction in case retrieval efforts fail (e.g., Anderson, 1983; Klein & Loftus, 1988).

According to the elaboration hypothesis, tasks that promote the best retention should be those that encourage participants to engage in the greatest amount of trace elaboration during encoding (Anderson & Reder, 1979; Craik & Tulving, 1975; Klein & Kihlstrom, 1986). The recall superiority of self-referent over structural and semantic encodings thus may be interpreted as indicating that self-reference is superior to these comparison tasks in its potential for creating an elaborate memory trace (Keenan & Baillet, 1980; Kendzierski, 1980; Rogers et al., 1977).

sec.title: The organizational processing hypothesis
sec.p: In 1986, Klein and Kihlstrom proposed that organization, rather than elaboration, may be responsible for the SRE. In contrast to elaborative processing, organizational processing results in the encoding of associations among list words by leading participants to think about the stimulus words in relation to one another. This relational information can include word-to-word associations and associations that emerge when words share a common category label (e.g., Battig & Bellezza, 1979).

Thus, the words dance and music can be organized both as direct associates of one another and under the category label “things connected with parties.” The process of organizing a list of words augments recall by establishing interitem associative paths in memory that can be used during retrieval (e.g., Srull, 1983) and category labels that can act as retrieval cues for category members (e.g., Tulving & Pearlstone, 1966).

Organizational processing can be assessed by examining the extent to which associated words are clustered during recall. A high degree of clustering is assumed to indicate the use of relational information as a basis for organizing stimulus words in memory. Using clustering analyses, Klein and Kihlstrom (1986) obtained evidence that self-referent judgments in the typical SRE experiment were more likely than semantic judgments to encourage the organization of list words. This suggested to them that the SRE may be due to organizational processing induced by self-referent encoding. Klein and Kihlstrom obtained support for this hypothesis in a series of studies by demonstrating that if self-reference tasks were compared with semantic tasks that encouraged similar organization, the self-referent recall advantage vanished.

sec.title: The elaborative + organizational processing hypothesis
sec.p: In a study designed to clarify the respective contributions of elaboration and organization to self-referential recall, Klein and Loftus (1988) demonstrated that self-reference differs from comparison encoding tasks in that it establishes an encoded representation having both item-specific (i.e., elaborative) and relational (i.e., organizational) information. Whether this two-factor encoding ultimately is more memorable than encodings induced by comparison tasks, however, depends both on stimulus conditions and on the task chosen for comparison.

Specifically, when stimulus material makes item-specific information salient (Hunt & Einstein, 1981), tasks promoting relational information will be most useful to recall. Accordingly, self-reference will be superior to an elaborative task but not to an organizational task. When stimulus material draws attention to relational information (e.g., Puff, 1979), tasks inducing encoding of item-specific information will benefit recall the most; consequently, the relative effectiveness of comparison tasks will be reversed. In this instance, self-reference will facilitate memory more than an organizational task but not more than an elaborative task. (For greater explication, see Klein & Loftus, 1988.)

Thus, the uniqueness of self-reference need not be assessed exclusively in terms of recall superiority. Rather, a qualitative distinction can be made: Although not necessarily more effective than elaborative or organizational tasks, self-reference is unique in its ability to promote good retention regardless of whether stimulus conditions favor tasks promoting elaborative or organizational processing.

A conclusion to be drawn from these results is that the effects of self-reference on recall cannot be accounted for by a single type of processing: Both elaborative and organizational processes appear to be involved, but which will play the larger role in recall cannot be predicted without an understanding of the conditions that determine the relative importance of elaborative and organizational processing at encoding (Klein & Loftus, 1988; strong support for this conclusion comes from Symons & Johnson’s, 1997, a meta-analytic review of SRE studies).

A dual-process explanation of self-referent encoding has implications for understanding the manner in which information processed in relation to the self may be represented in memory. Considerable research has shown that a stimulus may be represented in memory by item-specific or relational information (Begg, 1978; Einstein & Hunt, 1980; Humphreys, 1978), but the type of information encoded depends on the type of processing the stimulus receives. Because both elaborative and organizational processes appear to occur during self-referent encoding, the resulting memorial representation should incorporate both item-specific and relational information.

sec.title: Does the epistemological self have special mnemonic properties?
sec.p: Much of the initial interest in the SRE reflected the claim that the phenomenon was informative about the self as a structure in memory. Given the recall superiority of self-referent encodings, a number of investigators concluded that the self must have special properties that distinguish it from other memory structures (e.g., Greenwald, 1981; Kendzierski, 1980; Rogers, 1981; Rogers et al., 1977). Explaining this “uniqueness” soon became the prevalent focus of SRE research. However, several studies uncovered conditions under which self-referent recall did not exceed that of a comparison task (e.g., Bower & Gilligan, 1979; Ferguson et al., 1983; Klein & Kihlstrom, 1986; Lord, 1980; Maki & McCaul, 1985), leading some to suggest that the memorial effects of self-reference may be explained without attributing special mnemonic properties to the self (e.g., Brown et al., 1986; Kihlstrom & Cantor, 1984; Klein & Kihlstrom, 1986).

My colleagues and I have proposed that the question of whether the self has special mnemonic properties needs to be considered separately from the question of whether relating information to the self will always produce better recall than semantic encoding of the same material. For example, Klein and Loftus’s (1988) results suggested that self-reference differs from comparison tasks in that it establishes an encoded representation having both item-specific and relational information. Whether this two-factor encoding ultimately is more memorable than encodings induced by these tasks, however, depends both on stimulus conditions and on the task chosen for comparison. When stimulus material makes item-specific information salient, tasks promoting relational information will be most useful to recall. Accordingly, self-reference will be superior to an elaborative task but not to an organizational task. When stimulus material draws attention to relational information, tasks inducing encoding of item-specific information will benefit recall the most; consequently, the relative effectiveness of comparison tasks will be reversed. In this instance self-reference will be more facilitating than an organizational task but not more facilitating than an elaborative task.

In sum, the elaborative/organizational dual-process explanation has received wide support (see Symons & Johnson, 1997, for a meta-analytic review of the evidence) and appears a viable processing explanation regardless of whether traits (e.g., Klein & Kihlstrom, 1986, Experiment 1; Klein, Robertson, et al., 2011) or nouns (e.g., Burns, Burns, & Hwang, 2011; Klein & Loftus, 1988) serve as the to-be-remembered items.

sec.title: Problems: A Divergence of Results, Explanations, and Inferences Based on SRE Studies
sec.p: Across disciplines, the SRE is arguably the most widely used method of examining the memorial properties of the self and their relation to a host of psychologically interesting variables (see below). It has been the method of choice in hundreds of investigations, many of which have replicated Rogers et al.’s (1977) findings (for a partial review, see Symons & Johnson, 1997). In addition, the self-reference paradigm has been used to explore self-referent encoding under a staggering variety of theoretically interesting conditions. Researchers have examined the mnemonic effectiveness of self-reference as a function of private self-consciousness (Agatstein & Buchanan, 1984; Hull & Levy, 1979; Nasby, 1985), developmental stage in the aging process (Glisky & Marquine, 2009; Hamami, Serbun, & Gutchess, 2011; Mueller, Wonderlich, & Dugan, 1986; Sui & Zhu, 2005), creativity (Katz, 1987), autism (e.g., Hare, Mellor, & Azmi, 2007; Henderson et al., 2009; Lombardo, Barnes, Wheelwright, & Baron-Cohen, 2007), culture (Zhang et al., 2006; Zhu, Zhang, Fan, & Han, 2007), sex typing (Mills, 1983), neurological damage (Grilli & Glisky, 2010, 2011), Alzheimer’s dementia (Lalanne, Grolleau, & Piolino, 2010; Ruby et al., 2009), meditation (Han et al., 2010), attention deficit hyperactivity disorder (ADHD; Klein, Lax, et al., 2011), stimulus type (Klein & Loftus, 1988; Velichkovsky, 1999), stimulus valence (Glisky & Marguine, 2009), neuroticism (Young & Martin, 1981), social schemata and prototypes (Kuiper, 1981; Markus, 1977; Rogers, Rogers, & Kuiper, 1979), depression (Derry & Kuiper, 1981; Kuiper & Derry, 1982), self versus other processing (Bower & Gilligan, 1979; Kuiper & Rogers, 1979), and religion (Ge, Gu, Ji, & Han, 2009; Wu, Wang, He, Mao, & Zhang, 2010). The type of memory system involved in the self-referential decision (e.g., episodic vs. semantic; see Klein et al., 2008; Klein, Loftus, & Burton, 1989), familiarity of comparison-other (Klein et al., 1989; Kuiper & Rogers, 1979), and the specific wording of the self-referential task (Klein et al., 1989; Nairne, Thompson, & Pandeirada, 2007) have also been found to have substantial effects on whether an SRE recall advantage will be found. Finally, a large number of recent investigations into the neural localization of the self have used self-referential encoding processes in conjunction with brain imaging technologies (for review, see Legrand & Ruby, 2009; Northoff et al., 2005).

Several problems, however, have rendered the self-reference paradigm less theoretically fruitful than it promised to be. First, attempts to extend the paradigm have yielded conflicting results. For example, self-referent encoding has been compared with encoding in reference to a well-known other (e.g., one’s mother). In some studies self-referent encoding produced higher recall (e.g., Lord, 1980, Experiment 1), but in others it did not (e.g., Bower & Gilligan, 1979, Experiment 2).

Similarly, when nouns replaced trait adjectives as stimuli, some investigators reported that self-referent encoding led to greater recall than did semantic encoding (e.g., Klein & Loftus, 1988; Warren, Chattin, Thompson, & Tomsky, 1983); however, other investigators did not obtain this effect (e.g., Aboud, 1980; Velichkovsky, 1999). These inconsistencies have led some to question whether there really is a recall advantage for information encoded self-referentially. The conclusion of Higgins and Bargh (1987) is typical of this sentiment: “In brief, self-reference is neither necessary nor sufficient for memory of input to be facilitated in comparison to a semantic orientation task” (p. 392).

A second problem is that, among studies examining the same content area, varying results are found. For example, some investigators using the SRE to test the relation between self and memory in autism have found some evidence of SREs (Hare et al., 2007; Lombardo et al., 2010) whereas others have not (Henderson et al., 2009; Lind & Bowler, 2008). Similar variability in conclusions about the relation between self and memory are found in other areas of psychological inquiry when they rely on the SRE as their primary research instrument. For example, in testing whether SREs are present prior to age 8, Halpin, Puff, Mason, and Martson (1984) obtained null results of SRE manipulations whereas Sui and Zhu (2005) reported positive SREs.

Even within a set of studies, different findings from the same population (e.g., people with ADHD) are obtained when the self-referential processing task is varied with regard to the specific format of the encoding question used. For example, Klein, Lax, and Gangi (2011) showed that when self-referential recall is examined in young adults with ADHD, small changes in task instructions can yield large changes in recall. In their first study, participants were asked the standard SRE question: “Does this trait word describe you?” Under these conditions, ADHD participants produced a recall profile statistically indistinguishable from that produced by age-matched controls. However, in Study 2, the self-referential question was changed. Participants now were requested to retrieve a personal recollection (presumably from episodic memory) in which their behavior exemplified the presented trait words. Under these conditions, ADHD participants showed a weaker effect of self-reference on recall and evidenced significantly less organization in their recall compared with Study 1. So, do ADHD participants demonstrate a self-referential recall advantage comparable with participants not suffering from ADHD? It depends in a critical way on whether the stimulus traits are processed with respect to semantic self-knowledge (Study 1) or with respect to episodic self-knowledge (Study 2).

Yet another problem is that amount of familiarity with a task-referent (i.e., the person—self vs. other—to whom the encoding task judgments are directed) can determine the type of memory system involved in task performance even when the task requirements nominally remain the same (e.g., Klein, Loftus, Trafton, & Fuhrman, 1992). For example, even within the context of SRE tasks comparing trait judgments of self and other (e.g., “Describes you?” vs. “Describes Bob?”; Bower & Gilligan, 1979; Kuiper & Rogers, 1979), one cannot assume that semantic trait-knowledge is being activated by task demands. Familiarity with the “other” plays a crucial role (for review of the evidence, see Klein et al., 1992; Klein et al., 2008; Klein & Loftus, 1993).

When the to-be judged other is well-known or familiar, one reasonably can be assured that trait judgments are being made via access to semantic trait-knowledge. By contrast, when the comparison-other is one for whom familiarity is only partial, episodic recollections of the other’s trait-relevant behaviors are more likely to play the major role in judgments of trait applicability (e.g., Klein, Cosmides, et al., 2002; Klein & Loftus, 1993).

A recent set of studies of Buddhist practitioners brings this point into sharp relief. In one study (Han et al., 2010), self-referential judgments about the applicability of trait adjectives were better remembered when they were processed in reference to oneself than in reference to others. In contrast, Wu et al. (2010) found that self-referential processing of traits did not always produce better memory than did processing traits in relation to other. A possible reason for these discrepancies is that in the Han et al. (2010) study, the comparison-others were individuals for whom participants had little relevant first-person experience (e.g., the Chinese premier, Jesus). The Wu et al. (2010) study, by contrast, varied comparison-other familiarity. When comparison-others were individuals with whom participants had considerable personal familiarity (such as their mother), memory performance equaling self-referential encoding was found. By contrast, when the comparison-other was someone for whom participants lacked such experience (e.g., a famous Chinese author), memory performance was inferior to that associated with that produced by self-reference. Thus, SRE memory differences between these studies likely can be traced to differences in referent-familiarity as well as the particular memory system(s) involved in what, on the surface, would seem to be the same task demands.

Both studies also collected brain imaging data from their participants. Not surprisingly, similarities and differences in the neural substrates identified as mediating participants’ self-referential thought were found both within and between studies. Wu et al. (2010) attributed this variability to differences in the meditative practices of their participants. However, this conclusion must remain tentative in light of possible differences in memory systems and levels of referent-familiarity that characterize these two studies.4

Finally, on a related note, attempts to localize the self via brain imaging techniques have resulted in numerous conflicting results (for review, see Gillihan & Farah, 2005; Legrand & Ruby, 2009). As argued below, this is fully anticipated once one recognizes that (a) different self-reference tasks tap into different systems of memory (as discussed below); (b) the “self” that is the focus of self-referential processing tasks is not the ontological, causally relevant, self of first-person subjectivity, but rather the epistemological, memory-based self-referential knowledge that serves as the content for that subjectivity; and (c) the epistemological knowledge of self is distributed (within and between) a number of functionally independent systems of memory (for details, see Klein, 2010; Klein & Gangi, 2010; Klein & Lax, 2010).

sec.title: A Proposed Resolution
sec.p: In 1989, Klein et al. demonstrated that much of the controversy surrounding self-reference stemmed from a failure to distinguish between SREs produced in different experimental contexts. Specifically, at least two self-referent encoding tasks have been used to produce the SREs reported in the literature: a descriptive task variant in which participants decide whether a stimulus word is self-descriptive (i.e., “Describes you?”) and an autobiographical task variant in which participants retrieve an autobiographical memory related to a stimulus word (i.e., “Recall a time when”). The two tasks have been used interchangeably between and within self-reference studies. For example, some studies comparing the mnemonic effectiveness of self-reference with other-reference use descriptive tasks (e.g., Ferguson et al., 1983; Kuiper & Rogers, 1979), others use autobiographical tasks (e.g., Brown et al., 1986; Miall, 1986), and still others include both tasks in the same experiment (e.g., Bower & Gilligan, 1979; Friedman & Pullyblank, 1982).

Similar intermixing of tasks is found among studies investigating the processes mediating the SRE. Some studies rely exclusively on descriptive tasks to explore self-reference (e.g., Ferguson et al., 1983; Kendzierski, 1980; Rogers et al., 1977), some use autobiographical tasks (e.g., Bellezza, 1984; Bruss, 1986; Klein & Loftus, 1988), and others draw conclusions from studies that include both tasks (e.g., Bower & Gilligan, 1979; Klein & Kihlstrom, 1986).

Klein et al. (1989) argued that this treatment of descriptive and autobiographical tasks as equivalent methods for studying the SRE was responsible for much of the difficulty in demonstrating consistent effects of self-reference and in specifying the processes mediating the effect. The interchangeable use of these tasks reflected an assumption that they function similarly, but the only empirical basis for their assumed equivalence was a study by Bower and Gilligan (1979, Experiment 2). For each of a list of trait adjectives, Bower and Gilligan’s participants either decided whether the trait was self-descriptive or searched memory for a personal experience in which they had manifested the trait. The descriptive and autobiographical tasks produced comparable recall enhancement. However, many factors facilitate recall, so it is difficult to argue for process equivalence solely on the basis of recall equivalence.

Klein and colleagues presented evidence that descriptive and autobiographical tasks involve different cognitive processes and detailed how much of the variability in the SRE literature results from a failure to appreciate this difference. A large part of the difference between these two forms of the SRE task involves the memorial system providing epistemological self-knowledge. Klein and colleagues have amassed a large body of evidence over the last two decades that demonstrates that the “Describes you” variant of the SRE test entails the activation and retrieval of self-relevant information from semantic memory, whereas the “autobiographical” form of the task accesses self-relevant knowledge from episodic memory. The two primary forms of the SRE task thus activate and access different aspects of self-knowledge contained in different systems of memory (see Klein, 2001, 2004; Klein et al., 2008; Klein & Loftus, 1993).

Klein et al. (1989; see also Klein et al., 2008; Klein & Loftus, 1993) proposed that when SRE investigations are segregated on the basis of these two distinct SREs, a clearer picture of the role of the self in memory emerges. In a series of studies, they first replicated Bower and Gilligan’s (1979) finding that descriptive and autobiographical tasks yield comparable recall. They then presented evidence that, although autobiographical retrieval is required for the SRE obtained with the autobiographical task, it was not involved in performance of the descriptive task. Finally, they offered evidence against the possibility that descriptive and autobiographical tasks rely on a common process other than autobiographical retrieval to achieve their comparable mnemonic effectiveness.

Accordingly, a far more consistent picture of the literature on self-versus other-reference can be seen when the studies are grouped according to the task used in the investigation. In every study in which encoding in reference to a well-known other has involved autobiographical retrieval (e.g., “Recall an incident in which your mother exemplified this trait”), other-reference has produced recall comparable with that obtained with self-reference (Bower & Gilligan, 1979, Experiment 2; Brown et al., 1986, Experiment 5; Chew, 1983, Experiment 3; Miall, 1986).

In contrast, with a few exceptions (Friedman & Pullyblank, 1982, Experiment l; Kuiper & Rogers, 1979; Maki & McCaul, 1985), the use of descriptive tasks for making judgments about well-known others (e.g., “Does this trait describe your mother?”) has produced recall inferior to that found with self-reference (Bradley & Mathews, 1983; Chew, 1983, Experiment 2; Ferguson et al., 1983; Friedman & Pullyblank, 1982, Experiments 2 and 3; Karylowski & Buczek, 1984, Experiment 1; Kuiper & Derry, 1982, Experiment 2; Lord, 1980, Experiment 1).

A lack of consistency also has plagued studies testing whether self-reference enhances memory for nouns. Early demonstrations of the SRE (e.g., Kuiper & Rogers, 1979; Rogers et al., 1977) used trait adjectives as stimulus material. Attempts to obtain the effect using nouns, however, have produced discrepant results. Some studies have replicated the SRE with nouns (e.g., Klein & Kihlstrom, 1986; Warren et al., 1983), but others have not (e.g., Aboud, 1980; Maki & McCaul, 1985).

Grouping these studies according to the task used also introduces greater consistency. The SREs with nouns typically are obtained with self-reference tasks promoting autobiographical retrieval (Banaji & Greenwald, 1984; Brown et al., 1986, Experiments 5 and 6; Klein & Kihlstrom, 1986; Klein & Loftus, 1988; Warren et al., 1983; but see Bellezza, 1984, 1986). Studies failing to obtain SREs, however, have used self-reference tasks not requiring autobiographical retrieval, such as descriptive tasks (Aboud, 1980; Klein & Kihlstrom, 1986) and tasks in which participants create a mental image of themselves interacting with the noun (Karylowski & Buczek, 1984, Experiment 2; Lord, 1980, 1987; Maki & McCaul, 1985, Experiment 2; Pressley, Levin, Kuiper, Bryant, & Michener, 1982, Experiment 2).

Thus, although there are exceptions, a far more coherent picture of SRE research emerges when the findings are separated into those resulting from autobiographical tasks and those resulting from descriptive tasks. Although this classification scheme does not serve as the sole explanation for the differential effects of these tasks on other-referent and noun recall, the order it introduced into a research literature that had appeared inconsistent can provide direction to the theoretical understanding of these phenomena.

sec.title: Conclusion and Implications
sec.p: In recent years, research involving the SRE has gradually shifted from identifying mechanisms to using the SRE as a research tool for examining the nature of the self and its relation to memory. Assumptions about underlying mechanisms producing the SRE have largely been left unstated and unstudied. This, in turn, has led to conceptual confusion and a lack of clarity about the meaning of effects obtained. Specifically, to what aspect(s) of the epistemological self (e.g., semantic factual self-knowledge, semantic trait self-knowledge, episodic self-narratives?) do data obtained using SRE tasks refer?

In this article, I have highlighted several areas of consideration that should be embraced by anyone choosing to adopt the SRE paradigm as a way of gaining insight into the functioning of self in a particular population (e.g., developmental, neurological, clinical, personality subtype) or research domain (e.g., culture, gender, meditation, neural localization, schemata). By way of conclusion, I offer the following issues that investigators should consider when using the paradigm.

list-item.p: When using the SRE to test the self and its representation in memory, researchers should be aware that different task variables (e.g., traits vs. nouns), task referents (e.g., self vs. other, self vs. semantic processing), and memory systems (e.g., semantic vs. episodic) may be involved in task performance. And, depending on the nature of the materials being used, a high level of self-referential recall, if obtained, may be due to elaborative, organizational, or elaborative and organizational processing (for discussion of the respective contributions of the self-task vs. the stimulus items to elaborated and organized memory representation in the SRE, see Klein & Loftus, 1988).

The type of memory systems that mediate the SRE will vary as a function of the nature of the self-referential task (e.g., “Describes you?” vs. “Autobiographical”). Accordingly, investigators drawing conclusions from the use of the SRE task must be aware of the memory systems that are relevant to task performance.

sec.p: For example, whereas Halpin et al. (1984) failed to obtain SREs for children younger than 5 years, Sui and Zhu (2005) obtained reliable effects in the same population. An important difference, however, is that Halpin and colleagues asked their participants to make self-descriptiveness judgments about a list of traits, whereas Sui and Zhu had participants decide whether images of faces belonged to self or other (for similar mixing of tasks within the same set of studies, see Hamami et al., 2011).

In short, as I hope this review makes clear, there is no single epistemological source of self-knowledge. Many neural systems play a role. I have touched primarily on two forms of memory involved in self-knowledge, but, as my review suggests, other systems can come into play (e.g., imagery systems such as tasks asking participants to visually imagine the stimulus in relation to the self; Brown et al., 1986; Grilli & Glisky, 2010, 2011; Sui & Zhu, 2005).

Moreover, even within a type of memory, multiple aspects of self-knowledge can be functionally independent and hence dissociable. For example, Klein and Lax (2010) showed that semantic self-knowledge can be either factual or dispositional and that these two forms or self-knowledge are dissociable. Thus, within semantic memory, there are different systems of self-knowledge that may be selectively addressed during performance of self-referential processing depending on the framing of the self-referential task question.

list-item.p: 3. The evidence accrued from the SRE paradigm has far more to say about content in self-relevant memory systems (i.e., epistemological self-relevant knowledge) than it does about the ontological self. Memory systems contain various forms of knowledge that are self-relevant (e.g., traits such as “I am friendly,” facts such as “I was born in New York,” and events such as “I recall tripping over a stone during my morning jog”). Each of these epistemological sources of self is informative about neural representations of self-knowledge, but the degree to which such knowledge systems license statements about the ontological self—the self of everyday conscious experience—is far less clear.

sec.p: To the extent that researchers are interested in the “self” with regard to its causal role in a person’s behavior, or the recipient/participant of self-referential predicates (e.g., concept, depletion, esteem, image, reference, etc.), the SRE can, if properly understood, be a very useful research technique. That is, it is relevant to questions pertaining to how epistemological self-knowledge is represented in and retrieved from various systems of memory, and how these memory processes are influenced by context, task wording, stimulus items, and the specific systems involved. Investigators using the SRE to explore the self of first-person experience and endow it with causally relevant properties need to be cognizant of limitations in the type and scope of inferences they can make about the self from findings obtained with the SRE.

This confusion between meanings of the term self is brought into clear focus by the recent proliferation of brain-scanning studies attempting to locate the neural correlates of “self” using the SRE (e.g., Fossati et al., 2004; Kircher et al., 2000; Macrae, Moran, Heatherton, Banfield, & Kelley, 2004; for reviews and meta-analyses, see Gillihan & Farah, 2005; Northoff et al., 2005). As these reviewers lament, attempted localizations have been far from encouraging (for a discussion of the plurality of self and the possibility of its neural localization, see Ruby & Legrand, 2007).

One reason for these disappointing results is that the self being searched for by brain scanners is not the subjective, ontological self (which is not an object, and thus cannot be neurally localized), but rather a diverse collection of neurological systems that provide knowledge and experiences for the ontological self. They are independent of apprehension by the ontological self (though they can become objects for it), and thus neuroimaging analyses are warranted. However, the diversity of systems relevant to self-knowledge, and their presumed neural correlates, has the unintended result of showing the “self” to be an entity that lacks clear neural localization (for a related view, see Legrand & Ruby, 2009).

For example, different neural localizations are found when participants are asked to process traits for self-descriptiveness (i.e., semantic-based memory judgments; Kelley et al., 2002; Macrae et al., 2004) than when asked to perform tasks that entail retrieval of personal events from episodic memory (e.g., Andreasen et al., 1999). And both of these, in turn, yield different localizations of self than do studies requesting identification of images of oneself (e.g., Kircher et al., 2001; Udin, Kaplan, Molnar-Szakacs, Zaidel, & Iacaboni, 2005). Further complicating matters, a recent review of self-referential treatments of Alzheimer’s disease combined the results of self-tasks that entail access to semantic memory (e.g., “Describes you?”) with self-tasks prompting episodic retrieval (e.g., “Remember a time when XXX?”) to derive general conclusions (complete with supporting data from accompanying brain scans) about the role of episodic memory in Alzheimer’s dementia (Lalanne et al., 2010).

Complicating matters, the ontological self lacks a clear descriptive identity (see section one of this article). As Polanyi (1967) cautioned, “Either you know what you are looking for, and then there is no problem; or you do not know what you are looking for, and then you cannot expect to find anything” (p. 22). Small wonder meta-analytic assessments of the success of self-localization via imaging techniques have been so discouraging (e.g., Gillihan & Farah, 2005; Ruby & Legrand, 2007).

Put more positively, what these studies seem to be telling us is that the self is not a “thing” to be found, and thus the idea of localizing a neural entity called the “self” is a nonstarter (e.g., Klein, Lax, & Gangi, 2010). Ultimately, what carries as much importance as the specificity with which imaging techniques can capture neural activity (for critical discussion, see Bennett, Baird, Miller, & Wolford, 2010; Bennett & Miller, 2010; Miller et al., 2002; Uttal, 2009; Vul, Harris, Winkielman, & Pashler, 2009) is the specificity with which the constructs we submit to scanning capture the essence of what they are intended to describe (Uttal, 2001).

In sum, the self is perhaps the most complex and central topic in psychology (e.g., James, 1890). Current treatment of this core construct would benefit from greater attention to both logical analyses of what, at a minimum, we refer to when we study the self and a more nuanced consideration of the multifaceted nature of the neural systems of self-knowledge.

Some might argue that this really is not an issue at all. Psychologists know that the object (if it is an object!) of the predicate in the relation X (self)–Y (concept, depletion, image, regulation, reference, etc.) is really a “place holder” for the modifier (i.e., Y), which is the real focus of examination. However, if that is the case, then we run into uncertainty vis-à-vis which aspect of the X-Y relation is doing the causal work. If the former (i.e., X), then in what sense is a self causally efficacious such that it can, for example, be depleted. Does it loose air, phlogiston, ether, spreading activation? If Y, then how does depletion casually work on a construct that would appear to lack substance under the physicalist principle of causal closure (see Klein, in press-b, for an extended discussion)?

Put in somewhat different terms, if one is not going to require any work from X in the above causal relation (we all, after all is said and done, understand X, at least via acquaintance), then why even have it? Why not relabel the Journal of Self & Identity the Journal of Concept, Depletion, Image, Regulation, Reference, and Other Things People Might Do? The point is that if one wishes to discuss the self and not simply see it as a slot to be filled in at some future date, then theory and research that invoke it as a causally relevant factor in psychological mechanism need to give it the respect and attention it requires.

One reviewer astutely questions whether this proposition implies that the ontological self is (a) not reducible to neural functions in principle (it is based on something more than brain activity) or (b) that we cannot study its neural underpinnings because we cannot isolate it without making it an object of one’s perception. My response to this question is that both (a) and (b) are correct. Point (b), as I hope I have shown, is a logical consequence of the definitions of and relations between, the constructs of objectivity and subjectivity; Point (a) is a nonphysicalist assumption on my part. However, it is an assumption for which I offer empirical and theoretical backing in Klein (in press-a, in press-b).

To help clarify this important point, the epistemological “self” is the neurological basis of self-experience. That is, it consists in the brain mechanisms that provide the ontological self with knowledge of its internal and external environments. However, just as the thought, per se, is not the same as awareness of the thought (see above), so too, the source of data stored in memory from perceptual and introspective activities is not the same as, or reducible to, the experience of that data.

Unfortunately, even if the authors did consider differences in referent-familiarity and/or type of memory system mediating their findings, they do not explicitly discuss the extent to which these factors play any role in their formulation of causal explications of their data.
